6.title: nyu-dss/aperitiiif ðŸ¥‚ Work in Progress!
6.content: Small(ish) batch IIIF processing for digital research and scholarship.Leverages serverless-iiif, aws, and github.

8.title: Manage secrets and vars Work in Progress!

12.title: Architecture
12.content: . | Canonical Metadata and Image Data a. GitHub Repo . | IIIF Image API a. serverless-iiif implementation b. Source image S3 bucket c. GitHub Action uses aperitiiif gem to process images, syncs them to S3 source bucket . | IIIF Presentation API a. S3 bucket for published json b. GitHub Action uses aperitiiif gem to generate IIIF Presentation API resources, syncs them to S3 presentation bucket . | Discovery a. Github Action uses aperitiiif gem to generate 2 indices of resources produced (index.html for humans, index.json for machines), publishes them to Github Pages . | .

13.title: Workflow
13.content: Setup (GitHub) . | Admin creates repo for new collection using aperitiiif-batch-template named aperitiiif-batch-collectionname where collectionname will be the namespace used for resources generated. | Admin adds S3 secrets to the repo enviroment. | Admin enables Actions and GitHub pages on the repo. | Admin gives curator(s) write access to the repo. They can add images and metadata but cannot access settings or secrets. | . Ingest (GitHub) . | Curator adds images to src/data directory (multipart object structure TBD) and metadata via CSV file to src/metadata. | Curator adds metadata defaults as needed to the config.yml file | When committed to the main branch, a GitHub Action will convert images to tif, namespace them by prepending the collection name and any subfolder names, and sync them to the S3 source image bucket. | It will also use the Oâ€™Sullivan gem to generate Presentation API JSON resources (e.g., manifests, canvases, etc.) and sync them to the S3 presentation bucket. | Lastly, it will also create listings of resources published (html and json) and deploy them to GitHub pages. | . Publish (AWS) . | The Presentation API resources that have been synced are done and ready. There is no additional work for AWS to do. | The images synced to the S3 source image bucket are now accessible by the serverless-iiif lambda policy. Requests that hit the IIIF Image API lambdas (via Cloudfront) trigger derivative builds to an S3 cache bucket. | .
